citations.narrative:
The licensee does not have any form of identification on the adult dogs in the facility. Proper identification is essential to
ensure that each dog can be properly identified and to facilitate proper record keeping.
The licensee must obtain and provide each animal with an official form of identification at all times and to facilitate record
keeping requirements.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the Exercise Plan for Dogs, Acquisitions/ Dispositions, Inventory on Hand, and Contingency plan
were not available for review by the inspector. The review of records required by the Animal Welfare Act facilitates the
inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and evaluate animal welfare. The facility must
ensure that all records are available upon request during the inspection process.

The applicant had two dogs singly housed indoors in kennels that did not meet the required minimum amount of floor
space. The kennels measured 5.75 square feet.
1. A female pit, no ID, measured 26" inches long from the nose to the tail base. Thus, requiring 7.1 square feet of floor
space.
2. A male pit, no ID, measured 23.5 inches long. Thus, requiring 6 square feet of floor space.
Failure to meet the required minimum amount of floor space can lead to unnecessary animal discomfort and distress.
Each dog must be housed in a primary enclosure meeting the minimum amount of floor space as calculated by taking the
square sum of the length of the dog in inches plus 6 inches then divide the product by 144. The applicant must ensure
that primary enclosures used to house dogs meet the required minimum amount of floor space.
This inspection was a site approval inspection.
This site is not ready for approval to conduct activity covered under your current Animal Welfare Act License.
Conducting regulated activities at a non-approved site is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next new site approval inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
The licensee does not have any form of identification on the adult dogs in the facility. Proper identification is essential to 
ensure that each dog can be properly identified and to facilitate proper record keeping. 
The licensee must obtain and provide each animal with an official form of identification at all times and to facilitate record 
keeping requirements. 
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
At the time of inspection, the Exercise Plan for Dogs, Acquisitions/ Dispositions, Inventory on Hand, and Contingency plan 
were not available for review by the inspector. The review of records required by the Animal Welfare Act facilitates the 
inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and evaluate animal welfare. The facility must 
ensure that all records are available upon request during the inspection process. 
3.6(c)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The applicant had two dogs singly housed indoors in kennels that did not meet the required minimum amount of floor 
space. The kennels measured 5.75 square feet. 
1. A female pit, no ID, measured 26" inches long from the nose to the tail base. Thus, requiring 7.1 square feet of floor 
space. 
2. A male pit, no ID, measured 23.5 inches long. Thus, requiring 6 square feet of floor space. 
Failure to meet the required minimum amount of floor space can lead to unnecessary animal discomfort and distress. 
Each dog must be housed in a primary enclosure meeting the minimum amount of floor space as calculated by taking the 
square sum of the length of the dog in inches plus 6 inches then divide the product by 144. The applicant must ensure 
that primary enclosures used to house dogs meet the required minimum amount of floor space. 
 
This inspection was a site approval inspection. 
 
This site is not ready for approval to conduct activity covered under your current Animal Welfare Act License.

Conducting regulated activities at a non-approved site is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act. 
 
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next new site approval inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
 n
